Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2: Water Isotopes in Peat Mosses as Proxies for Understanding Climate and Atmospheric Circulation Changes in Southern Patagonia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to Lehigh and Brown Universities will develop and test a powerful technique to reconstruct atmospheric circulation patterns and moisture trajectories using two water isotopes from peat mosses. The research will generate important climate records that will potentially transform our understanding of climate dynamics of the last 1000 years in the relatively understudied southern hemisphere. This approach is also applicable over longer time scales in this geographic regions, as well as other places Sphagnum moss can be found. The new climate records from under-studied southern Patagonia will provide a benchmark data set with which to evaluate the climate models that are used for projecting future climate change. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students at both institutions in the application of a state-of-art technology in innovative interdisciplinary research.

This award will use isotope records to document and understand climate and atmospheric circulation changes in the last millennium using a novel dual water isotope approach and systematic modern calibration from single species peat mosses (Sphagnum) as preserved in peat bogs in southernmost Patagonia (southern South America). The investigators will carry out calibration sampling and analysis to span large latitude and precipitation gradients in southern Patagonia. The isotope records will be derived from the existing peat cores at Lehigh University. In addition to using oxygen and hydrogen isotope time series from cellulose and lipids for ?conventional? paleoclimate interpretations, the team will explore the use of derived deuterium excess (delta-excess) as a tracer for moisture source region conditions and moisture trajectories. This innovative use of dual (O and D) isotopes would provide powerful information regarding past atmospheric circulation and mechanisms of observed climate changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We carried out cellulose and lipid isotope analysis on modern calibration samples collected during the January 2016 field trip. Along with the moss water isotope data and field data of moss water contents, we explore the isotopic hydrological process of peat bogs, evaluate the environmental controls on isotopic composition of Sphagnum moss, and propose a strategy for interpreting down-core variations for paleoclimatic reconstruction. Both cellulose and lipid carbon isotope values are very sensitive to water table depth and water content. But the cellulose oxygen isotopic values and lipid hydrogen isotopic values are less sensitive than their carbon isotopic values, particularly for lipid hydrogen isotopic values. There is strong negative correlation between Sphagnum moss cellulose oxygen and carbon isotopic data. Such correlation is useful to diagnose the down-core shifts in cellulose oxygen isotopic and carbon isotopic values.

 

 We analyzed the peat property, botanical composition, and isotopic compositions of cellulose and lipids in a radiocarbon-dated peat core from Ariel Peatland (AP). The data provide new constraints and insights into the hydroclimate variability and atmospheric circulation of southern Patagonia over the late Holocene. To strengthen the interpretation that links (meteoric) water isotopic compositions to moisture sources and trajectories, we explore the use of HYSPLIT equipped with the moisture uptake algorithm to quantify the impacts of moisture sources and trajectories on isotopic composition in precipitation recorded by GNIP stations.  We obtained macrofossils and cellulose oxygen and carbon isotopic data and lipid δD data for the last ~5,000 years, and these time series provide constraints and insights into the late Holocene hydroclimate variability and atmospheric circulation of southern Patagonia. Down-core cellulose carbon isotopic variations are tightly tracking the up-and-downs of Sphagnum macrofossil abundance shifts. We interpret the cellulose oxygen isotopic variations primarily reflecting the conditions of atmospheric circulation. It is supported by strong synchronous shifts during the last millennium between cellulose oxygen isotopic values and the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) index reconstructed from temperature-sensitive proxy network. During the negative phase of SAM, weakened westerly induces less Andes rain-shadow effect (wetter condition) and increasing moisture contribution from other sources, including the moisture brought by southerly and easterly that do not experience strong isotopic distillation from orographic rainfall, resulting in lower oxygen isotopic values. During the positive phase of SAM, strengthened westerly enhances the rain-shadow effect of study site (drier condition) and produces 18O-depleted rainfall at the study site. The lipid hydrogen isotopic data have lower resolution due to lower abundance or even absence of Sphagnum and n-alkane C23; the paired cellulose oxygen isotopic data and lipid hydrogen isotopic values enable inversed calculation of d-excess of moss water, which are, however, influenced by both Local Meteoric Water Line (LMWL) and Local Evaporation Line (LEL).

Broader impact: The project at Brown University has helped supporting graduate student Yinsui Zheng for her Ph.D. thesis research, training Brown undergraduate students on various lab techniques and contributed to maintenance of the modern organic and stable isotopic research facility, which is used by many other graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs. Lehigh University graduate student Zhengyu Xia has recieved training in sample preparation for lipid and isotopic analysis at Brown University. PI and graduate students have brought local GK-12 students to Brown for lab visits, introducing them to state-of-the-art research tools and findings.
